revision.text:
{{Short description|American actress and comedian}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{use American English|date=January 2020}} {{For|the British businesswoman|Carol Kane (businesswoman)}} {{Infobox person | name = Carol Kane | image = Carol Kane (2018) (cropped).jpg | caption = Kane in 2018 | birth_name = Carolyn Laurie Kane | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|06|18}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/artist/carol-kane-p36788|title=Carol Kane movies, photos, movie reviews, filmography, and biography - AllMovie|work=[[AllMovie]]|publisher=[[RhythmOne|All Media Network]]|access-date=March 22, 2015}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Actress, comedian | years_active = 1966–present }} '''Carolyn Laurie Kane''' (born June 18, 1952) is an [[United States|American]] [[actor|actress]] and comedian. She became known in the 1970s and 1980s in films such as ''[[Hester Street (film)|Hester Street]]'', for which she received an [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] nomination, ''[[Annie Hall]]'', and ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]''. She appeared on the television series ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' in the early 1980s, as Simka Gravas, the wife of [[Latka Gravas|Latka]], the character played by [[Andy Kaufman]], winning two [[Emmy Award]]s for her work. She has played the character of [[List of Wicked characters#Madame Morrible|Madame Morrible]] in the musical ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', both in regional productions and on Broadway from 2005 to 2014. From 2015 to 2019, she was a main cast member on the [[Netflix]] original series ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]'', in which she played Lillian Kaushtupper. == Early life == Kane was born in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], the daughter of Joy, a [[jazz]] singer, teacher, dancer, and pianist, and Michael Kane.filmreference.com. Retrieved August 27, 2011. Her family is [[Jews|Jewish]], and her grandparents emigrated from Russia, Austria, and Poland.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070320084513/http://www.open.org/glennab/carolkanefanbio.htm "Carol Kane Unofficial Fan Page" at the Wayback Machine]https://www.cbr.com/hunters-carol-kane-interview/ Her parents divorced when she was 12 years old.{{Cite web|url=http://www.open.org/glennab/cktvguidemay1983.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=September 27, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230511/http://www.open.org/glennab/cktvguidemay1983.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df=mdy}} She attended the Cherry Lawn School, a boarding school in [[Darien, Connecticut]], until 1965.[http://www.cherrylawnschool.org/directory/class/clstbl65.html "Cherry Lawn School, Class of 1965"] CherryLawnSchool.org. Retrieved August 27, 2011.[http://www.cherrylawnschool.org/pom/photomonth199910.html "Cherry Lawn School Photo Of The Month, October 1999"] CherryLawnSchool.org. Retrieved August 27, 2011. She studied theatre at [[HB Studio]][https://hbstudio.org/about-hb-studio/alumni/ HB Studio Alumni] and also went to the [[Professional Children's School]], in New York City, and made her professional theatre debut in a 1966 production of ''[[The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (novel)|The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie]]'', starring [[Tammy Grimes]].[https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800020210/bio "Carol Kane Biography"] YahooMovies. Retrieved August 27, 2011. == Career == === Television === Kane portrayed Simka Dahblitz-Gravas, wife of Latka Gravas ([[Andy Kaufman]]), on the American television series ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'', from 1981 to 1983. She received two [[Emmy Award]]s for her work in the series.{{Cite news|last1=Lacher|first1=Irene|title=Moving a Step Beyond|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/may/11/entertainment/et-lacher11|access-date=January 28, 2016|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 11, 2002}} In 1984, Kane appeared in episode 12, season 3 of ''[[Cheers]]'' as Amanda, an acquaintance of [[Diane Chambers]] from her time spent in a mental institution. Kane was a regular on the 1986 [[NBC]] series ''All Is Forgiven'', a regular on the 1990–1991 [[NBC]] series ''[[American Dreamer (TV series)|American Dreamer]]'', guest-starred on a 1994 episode of ''[[Seinfeld]]'', a 1996 episode of ''[[Ellen (TV series)|Ellen]]'' and had a supporting role in the short-lived 1996–1997 sitcom ''[[Pearl (TV series)|Pearl]]''. In 1988, Kane appeared in the [[Cinemax Comedy Experiment]] ''[[Rap Master Ronnie|Rap Master Ronnie: A Report Card]]'' alongside [[Jon Cryer]] and the [[Smothers Brothers]]. In January 2009, she appeared in the television series ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'' as the mother of Alan Harper's receptionist.[http://www.tv.com/two-and-a-half-men/thank-god-for-scoliosis/episode/1244269/summary.html Two and a Half Men: Thank God for Scoliosis Season 6"] TV.com. Retrieved August 27, 2011. In March 2010, Kane appeared in the television series ''[[Ugly Betty]]'' as Justin Suarez's acting teacher. In 2014, she had a recurring role in the TV series ''[[Gotham (TV series)|Gotham]]'' as Gertrude Kapelput, [[Oswald Cobblepot (Gotham)|Oswald Cobblepot's (Penguin's)]] mother.IMDb.com [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3993368/combined ''Gotham'': "Spirit of the Goat" (episode)]; retrieved October 28, 2014. In 2015, she was cast as Lillian Kaushtupper, the landlord to the title character of [[Netflix]]'s original series ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.voxmagazine.com/2015/03/unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-is-a-great-addition-to-netflix-lineup|title=Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt is a great addition to Netflix lineup {{!}} Vox Magazine|work=Vox Magazine|publisher=[[Columbia Missourian]]|last=Havey|first=Max|date=March 20, 2015|access-date=March 22, 2015}} In 2020, Kane was part of the ensemble cast of the Amazon show ''[[Hunters (2020 TV series)|Hunters]]'', which includes [[Al Pacino]] and [[Logan Lerman]], among other. === Films === [[File:Carol Kane Gene Wilder 1977.jpg|thumb|Kane and [[Gene Wilder]] in a publicity photo for ''[[The World's Greatest Lover]]'', 1977]] Kane appeared in ''[[The Last Detail]]'' (1973), ''[[Annie Hall]]'' (1977), ''[[The World's Greatest Lover]]'' (1977), ''Norman Loves Rose'' (1982), ''[[Dog Day Afternoon]]'' (1975), ''[[When a Stranger Calls (1979 film)|When A Stranger Calls]]'' (1979),''[[Transylvania 6-5000 (1985 film)|Transylvania 6-5000]]'' (1985), ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]'' (1987), ''[[Flashback (1990 film)|Flashback]]'' (1989) with [[Dennis Hopper]], and ''[[Scrooged]]'' (1988), in which ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called her "unquestionably [the] pic's comic highlight."[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117794690.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0 "Scrooged"] Variety (requires registration). Retrieved August 27, 2011. In 1998, she played Mother Duck on the cartoon movie ''[[The First Snow of Winter]]''. In 1999 she made a cameo on the movie ''[[Man on the Moon (film)|Man On The Moon]]'' as her character she played on ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]''. [[File:Hester Street (1975 poster).jpg|thumb|Kane was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] for her performance in ''[[Hester Street (film)|Hester Street]]'' (1975).]] At the [[48th Academy Awards]], Kane was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] for her role in the film ''[[Hester Street (film)|Hester Street]]''. === Theatre === She starred in the [[off-Broadway]] play ''[[Love, Loss, and What I Wore]]'' in February 2010.BWW News Desk.[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/LOVE_LOSS_AND_WHAT_I_WORE_Welcomes_Comedic_New_Cast_Janeane_Garofalo_Carol_Kane_More_Bow_23_20091210 " 'Love, Loss And What I Wore' Welcomes Comedic New Cast; Janeane Garofalo, Carol Kane & More Bow 2/3"] broadwayworld.com, December 10, 2009. Kane made her West End debut in January 2011 in a major revival of [[Lillian Hellman]]'s drama ''[[The Children's Hour (play)|The Children's Hour]]'', at London's [[Harold Pinter Theatre|Comedy Theatre]]. She starred alongside [[Keira Knightley]], [[Elisabeth Moss]] and [[Ellen Burstyn]].Shenton, Mark.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/145106-Ellen-Burstyn-and-Carol-Kane-Join-Cast-of-West-Ends-Childrens-Hour Ellen Burstyn and Carol Kane Join Cast of West End's Children's Hour] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018225802/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/145106-Ellen-Burstyn-and-Carol-Kane-Join-Cast-of-West-Ends-Childrens-Hour |date=October 18, 2012}} Playbill.com, November 19, 2010. In May 2012, Kane appeared on Broadway as Betty Chumley in a revival of the play ''[[Harvey (play)|Harvey]]''. ==== ''Wicked'' ==== Kane is known for her portrayal of the evil headmistress [[List of Wicked characters#Madame Morrible|Madame Morrible]] in the Broadway musical ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', whom she played in various productions from 2005 to 2014. Kane made her ''Wicked'' debut on the 1st National Tour, playing the role from March 9 through December 19, 2005. She then reprised the role in the Broadway production from January 10 through November 12, 2006. She again played the role for the Los Angeles production which began performances on February 7, 2007. She left the production on December 30, 2007, and later returned from August 26, 2008 until the production closed on January 11, 2009. She then transferred with the L.A. company, to play the role once again, in the San Francisco production which began performances January 27, 2009.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/san-francisco/news/12-2008/garrison-kane-kassebaum-wicks-set-for-san-francisc_13504.html|title=Garrison, Kane, Kassebaum, Wicks Set for San Francisco Wicked|author=Dan Bacalzo|date=December 16, 2008}} She ended her limited engagement on March 22, 2009.{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126830-Academy-Award-Winner-Duke-to-Join-Cast-of-San-Frans-Wicked |title=Academy Award Winner Duke to Join Cast of San Fran's Wicked |author=Andrew Gans |date=March 2, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140105034603/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126830-Academy-Award-Winner-Duke-to-Join-Cast-of-San-Frans-Wicked |archivedate=January 5, 2014}} Kane returned to the Broadway company of ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'' from July 1, 2013, through February 22, 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://playbill.com/news/article/179391-Broadways-Wicked-Will-Welcome-Carol-Kane-and-Michael-Wartella |title=Broadway's Wicked Will Welcome Carol Kane and Michael Wartella |date=June 21, 2013 |access-date=August 30, 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829040034/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/179391-Broadways-Wicked-Will-Welcome-Carol-Kane-and-Michael-Wartella |archivedate=August 29, 2013}} == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film |- !
